http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/SciValFunders/100014717 http://sws.geonames.org/1814991/ Mingfei Shao (State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology) received his Ph.D. degree from Beijing University of Chemical Technology (BUCT) in 2014, after which he joined the staff of BUCT and was promoted to professor in 2018. He was also a visiting student at the University of Oxford in 2013. His research interests mainly include electrochemical energy related chemistry, materials and engineering. He proposed the idea of the water electrolysis coupled with green electrosynthesis (e.g., hydrogen generation coupled with organic oxidation). He also proposed a new method of integrated electrode design based on layered double hydroxides, which is a platform for construct various energy materials and devices. He has been published more than 130 papers, which have been cited >13000 times (H index = 62). In addition, He has obtained and awarded from the National Natural Science Foundation of China\u2013Outstanding Youth Foundation in 2019 and the Chinese Catalytic Rookie Award. Zhenhua Li (College of Chemistry, Beijing University of Chemical Technology), received his B.S. in 2014 and Ph.D degree in 2019 from Beijing University of Chemical Technology. In 2017, he completed a joint doctoral training program at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore; From 2019 to 2023, he served as an associate professor at Beijing University of Chemical Technology, and promoted to professor from 2024. His research interests lie in the field of water electrolysis for hydrogen production couple with organic synthesis. He has published over 70 SCI papers, with more than 5800 citations, 11 ESI highly cited papers, and an H-index of 41. In the last five years, he has led a National Key R&D Program (Hydrogen Special)-Young Scientist Project, a National Natural Science Foundation of China-Youth Program, a Beijing Natural Science Foundation-Youth Program, and participated in two National Natural Science Foundation of China Major Programs. This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (22090031, 22108008, 22302006, 22288102), the Young Elite Scientist Sponsorship Program by CAST (2021QNRC001), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (buctrc202011), and the National Funded Postdoctoral Researchers Program (GZB20230049). item S1872-2067(24)60080-X S187220672460080X Review Cation effects in electrocatalytic reduction reactions: Recent advances Qinghui Ren a Liang Xu b * Mengyu Lv a Zhiyuan Zhang c Zhenhua Li a c * Mingfei Shao a c * Xue Duan a c a State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, College of Chemistry, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering College of Chemistry Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, College of Chemistry, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China b College of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China College of Chemical Engineering Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China College of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China c Quzhou Institute for Innovation in Resource Chemical Engineering, Quzhou 324000, Zhejiang, China Quzhou Institute for Innovation in Resource Chemical Engineering Quzhou Zhejiang 324000 China Quzhou Institute for Innovation in Resource Chemical Engineering, Quzhou 324000, Zhejiang, China * Corresponding author. Electrocatalytic reduction reactions, powered by clean energy sources such as solar energy and wind, offer a sustainable method for converting inexpensive feedstocks (e.g., CO2, N2/NO x , organics, and O2) into high-value-added chemicals or fuels. The design and modification of electrocatalysts have been widely implemented to improve their performance in these reactions. However, bottlenecks are encountered, making it challenging to further improve performance through catalyst development alone. Recently, cations in the electrolyte have emerged as critical factors for tuning both the activity and product selectivity of reduction reactions. This review summarizes recent advances in understanding the role of cation effects in electrocatalytic reduction reactions. First, we introduce the mechanisms underlying cation effects. We then provide a comprehensive overview of their application in electroreduction reactions. Characterization techniques and theoretical calculation methods for studying cation effects are also discussed. Finally, we address remaining challenges and future perspectives in this field. We hope that this review offers fundamental insights and design guidance for utilizing cation effects, thereby advancing their development. Graphical Abstract This review summarizes and discusses the mechanisms of cation effects, their applications, characterization techniques, and theoretical calculation methods in cation effects, while also offering future perspectives in this research area. Keywords Electrocatalysis Reduction reaction Cation effect Mechanism Application 1 Introduction Electrochemical technologies offer a promising approach for the effective storage, conversion, and utilization of renewable energy with low carbon emissions [1–6]. Among these technologies, electrocatalytic reduction, which directly uses water as a hydrogen source, is recognized as an environmentally friendly and sustainable method. This includes the electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [7–11], the electrocatalytic nitrogen (N2) or nitrate (NO3 –) reduction reaction (NRR or NITRR) [12,13], the reduction of organics to synthesize high-value chemicals [14–16], and the electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [17–20]. However, their sluggish kinetics, low current density, and poor selectivity limit their wide application. Over the past decade, significant efforts have been made to design efficient electrocatalysts to improve the performance of electrocatalytic reduction [21–26]. Various strategies can be employed in designing electrocatalysts, such as single/dual atom catalysts [27–29], two-dimensional layered catalysts [30], and three-dimensional porous catalysts [31,32]. These strategies include morphology control [33,34], construction of heterostructures [35,36], electronic orbital control [37,38], domain limiting [39,40], and others. However, current strategies for regulating catalysts may hit a bottleneck in further improving catalytic activity and selectivity. In addition to catalyst design, the reaction microenvironment such as the electrolyte, also plays a crucial role in enhancing catalytic activity. Notably, tuning the cations in the electrolyte has emerged as an effective strategy to improve electrocatalytic activity and selectivity (Fig. 1 , development history of cation effects) [41–47]. The interaction between the electrode and electrolyte interface can significantly influence electrocatalytic performance [48–51]. At the electrode-electrolyte interface, known as the electrical double layer (EDL)), which consists of the inner layer Helmholtz plane (IHP), the outer Helmholtz plane (OHP), and the diffusion layer [41,52], cations in the electrolyte can affect the surface charge of electrodes, the dielectric constant of electrolyte solutions, and non-covalent interactions between ions and water molecules, thereby influencing catalyst activity and selectivity [53,54]. Taking CO2RR as an example, Koper et al. [55] found that only CO was produced on the Au electrode with cations in the electrolyte. These cations stabilize the CO2 − intermediate via short-range electrostatic interaction, promoting its reduction. _ENREF_24Several interrelated mechanisms have been proposed to explain the cation effects, including the effect of the interfacial electric field [56–60], local pH [61–64], and the stabilization of intermediates [46,65,66]. These multifarious mechanisms present both opportunities and challenges for developing electrocatalytic interfaces that yield the desired products with high catalytic activity and selectivity. Furthermore, most current reviews on cation effects mainly focus on CO2RR, HER, and ORR [48,67–71] with less emphasis on other electrocatalytic reduction reactions. Therefore, to gain a comprehensive understanding of cation effects on catalytic reduction reactions, it is essential to explore these effects in other reactions as well. Here, we provide an overview of recent insights into the effects of cations on electrochemical reduction reactions (Fig. 2 ). First, we summarize the mechanisms of cation effects, such as promoting reactant adsorption/stabilization of intermediates, tuning the local electric field, buffering the interfacial pH, and influencing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activity. Subsequently, we review the effects of cations on typical electrocatalytic reduction reactions, including the CO2RR, NRR/NITRR, organic reduction, and ORR. Moreover, we discuss in detail the relationship between cations and the activity and selectivity of electrocatalytic reactions. Finally, we present future perspectives for this research area. 2 The mechanism of cation effects Since the discovery of cation effects, numerous hypotheses have been proposed to understand the underlying mechanisms. As previously mentioned, many important processes in electrochemical reactions, occur in the EDL, such as charge transfer between the electrode and reaction intermediates. Therefore, it is necessary to systematically understand the mechanisms of cation effects. Cation effects are diverse and include the following aspects: (1) adsorption/stabilization of reactants/intermediates, (2) tuning the local electric field, (3) buffering the interfacial pH, and (4) influencing the HER activity during reduction reactions. Although these four mechanisms are closely related (Fig. 3 ), categorizing them helps to better understand the main reaction mechanisms involved in the process. 2.1 Adsorption/stabilization of reactants/intermediates One typical effect of cations is the enhancement of reactant adsorption or the stabilization of intermediates [11,46,72,73]. Recently, Hu et al. [74] reported a K+ concentration gradient strategy to enhance activity and tune selectivity for CO2RR on Cu, Ag, and In catalysts. Moreover, computational simulations showed that the binding energies of intermediates changed under different K+ concentrations due to local electrostatic interactions modulated by K+ on the electrode surface (Ag and Cu) [74]. In another study, Melander et al. used density functional theory molecular dynamics (DFT-MD) to investigate the effect of cations (e.g., K+) on inner-sphere electron transfer (IS-ET) and outer-sphere electron transfer (OS-ET) during CO2RR (Fig. 4(a) ) [75]. They found that cations (K+) attract CO2 molecule to the Au (111) surface more effectively than pure water, thereby facilitating CO2 adsorption on Au (111) due to Coulombic interactions between the positively charged ions and the oxygen lone pair in CO2, which carries a partial negative charge. This promotes the activation of CO2 molecules (Fig. 4(b)) [75]. In addition to enhancing the adsorption of reactants, cation effects can also stabilize the intermediates. For example, Hwang et al. [76] found that cations such as Li+, Na+, K+, and Cs+ can stabilize *CO intermediates on a Cu(OH)2-derived catalyst in real-time through operando surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy at −1.0 V vs. RHE. During the reaction, as the size of the hydrated ions decreased from Li+ to Cs+, the electric field of the EDL was reinforced [55]. Increasing the surface charge density of Cu(OH)2 or enhancing the electric field can stabilize intermediates and significantly impact CO2RR activity (Fig. 4(c)). Time-resolved surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TR-SERS) measurements showed dynamic changes between the two *CO species: high-frequency binding (*COHFB) and low-frequency binding (*COLFB). The rapid initial adsorption of *COHFB was observed, followed by a steady ratio between *COLFB and *COHFB (Fig. 4(d)) [76]. 2.2 Tuning of the local electric field Accumulating cations near the surface of an ion can create an electric field through noncovalent interactions [56,60,77,78]. Modifying the potential of the plane on which electron transfer occurs can alter the apparent activation energy of the overall reaction, influence the interfacial water energetics, and affect substrate adsorption [55]. For example, N⊘rskov et al. [57] found that *CO2 and *COOH intermediates have high free energy and *CO desorbs easily on Ag (111) without an interfacial electric field. Applying an interfacial electric field of −1 V Å−1 stabilized the *CO2 and *COOH intermediates, effectively mitigating the thermodynamic barriers associated with these energetically favorable species (Fig. 5(a) ) [57]. Additionally, free energy values were calculated using density functional theory (DFT) in the presence of cations. It indicated that the main reason for the stability of the intermediates was the electrostatic interaction between the local electric field and the *CO2 generated by the cations (Fig. 5(b)) [57]. Furthermore, the size of the cation and its impact on the electric field at the interface are critical factors in determining the ion specificity of electrochemical reduction [56]. Chan et al. [56] presented a multiscale modeling approach that combined size-modified Poisson-Boltzmann theory with absolute simulations of field effects on critical reaction intermediates. The surface charge density and electric field decreased depending on the hydrated cation repulsion at the OHP (Fig. 5(c)). Cations such as Cs+ have a smaller hydrated cation radius and less repulsion close to the Ag electrode, leading to higher concentrations of cations, which results in a larger surface charge density and stronger interfacial electric field, which drives the adsorption of CO2 (Fig. 5(d)) [56]. 2.3 Buffering of interfacial pH Cations act as interfacial pH regulators, with larger ions exhibiting enhanced buffering capacity, thereby reducing the local pH [63,79,80]. Hori et al. [81] studied electrochemical CO2 and CO reduction on Cu electrodes in hydrogen carbonate solutions with various cations. They found that cation species (such as Li+, Na+, K+, and Cs+) affect the OHP potential, which in turn influences the concentration of H+ on the electrode, causing a change in the surface pH of the electrode and leading to variations in product selectivity. Recently, Bell et al. [77] reported that the pKa of the hydrolysis reaction is influenced by the size of the cation, and the interfacial pH over the Ag electrode during CO2RR follows the trend: Li+ > Na+ > K+ > Cs+ (Fig. 6(a) ). When the pKa of the hydrated cations is lower than the local pH, one of the hydrated ions releases protons, thus buffering the local pH. Moreover, maintaining a pH at the interface closer to that in the bulk can increase the CO2 concentration at the interface of the Ag electrode, thus enhancing catalytic activity and FE of the products (Fig. 6(b)) [77]. In addition, Ayemoba et al. [82] probed the pH at the electrochemical interface using in situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) (Fig. 6(c)). They demonstrated that large cations (Ag, Cu, and Au) can reduce the local pH at the electrode surface. Their results provided strong experimental support for the theoretical predictions of Bell et al. [77] (Fig. 6(d)). 2.4 Influencing HER activity during reduction reactions In the aforementioned electrochemical reduction reactions, water electrolysis (Volmer reaction: H2O + e− → H* + OH−) can provide H* donors for substrate reduction and also produce H2 easily, making the HER a typically competing process [83–85]. Recently, Koper et al. [86] investigated the influence of multivalent cations (Li+, Cs+, Be2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Nd3+, and Ce3+) on the CO2RR and competing HER over Au electrodes. They found that acidic cations with moderate hydration radii, such as Nd3+ and Ce3+, could enhance the CO2RR at low potentials (acidic electrolyte), whereas weakly hydrated cations such as Cs+ could facilitate the CO2RR at high potentials (alkaline/neutral electrolyte). This difference in performance was attributed to the varying abilities of metal cations to reduce water in different environments. The multivalent cations (such as Be2+, Al3+, Nd3+, and Ce3+) exhibited higher activity for water reduction (10-fold) than the other cations, suggesting that these cations may favor the HER over the CO2RR (Figs. 7(a) and (b) ) [86]. Additionally, cations can inhibit the HER in acidic electrolytes. Recently, Hu et al. [79] reported the CO2RR in a strongly acidic electrolyte (pH = 1), where the cation significantly inhibited the HER competition reaction. In a K+-containing electrolyte, a chemically inert hydrated K+ layer forms at the OHP due to the competitive adsorption of hydrated K+ ions and hydronium ions at the electrode OHP. This can shield the electric field of the cathode and suppress the migration of hydronium, thus inhibiting HER activity (Fig. 7(c)). Similar to K+, other cations (Li+, Na+, and Cs+) can form hydrogenated cations that shield the cathode electric field (Li+ < Na+ < K+ < Cs+) on the SnO2/C catalyst, increasing the FE of formic acid from 25.2% (Li+) to 81.0% (Cs+) (Fig. 7(d)). Although cation effects can enhance the activity, selectivity, and FE of electrocatalytic reduction reactions, some challenges still need to be addressed. For instance, the introduction of alkali cations into acidic electrolytes can lead to the crystallization of alkali salts on the cathode, thereby affecting overall energy consumption, stability, and shortening the lifespan of the cell [87]. In addition, in reduction reactions of organic compounds, cations may react with the reactants to form precipitates, which is also detrimental to the reaction [88]. To better address these issues, we have discussed them in the “Conclusion and outlook” section. 3 Applications Utilizing their impact on the behavior of cations in the electrolyte, cation effects can serve as a promising strategy for various electrochemical reactions [82,89–92]. In this section, we focus on improving the electrocatalytic performance of the CO2RR, NRR/NITRR, and the electrocatalytic reduction of organics through cation effects, with the aim of offering valuable insights into cation effects for electrocatalytic processes (Tables 1 and 2 ). 3.1 CO2RR The CO2RR presents a promising route for producing valuable chemicals in a carbon-neutral energy cycle [104–108]. Cation effects in CO2RR result in increased activity and selectivity toward the target products [94,109–113]. Sargent et al. [58] reported that Au nanoneedle electrodes can produce local high electric fields at low applied overpotentials, leading to local K+ aggregation. This aggregation enhances the concentration of CO2 on the electrode, promotes CO2 reduction, and suppresses the HER. A DFT study also revealed that with concentrated K+, CO2 could be quickly stabilized on the Au tips, thereby increasing the reduction current of the CO2RR (Figs. 8(a) and (b) ). Moreover, cations can influence the CO2RR to produce C2+. For example, Hori et al. [114] observed that the selectivity ratio of C2+ to C1 products on Cu improved nearly 12-fold from Li+ to Cs+ in the electrolyte, accompanied by an increase in the C2+ partial current density. Liu et al. [100] reported that regulating the arrangement of Cu nanoneedle arrays can influence the local electric field, thus influencing the CO2 reduction activity. Compared with disordered Cu nanoneedle arrays (CuNNs), ordered Cu nanoneedle arrays (CuNNAs) exhibit a high FE for multicarbon products (59% vs. 20%, Table 2). CuNNAs induce a strong local electric field at the tips of the catalyst and promote K+ aggregation, which benefits both *CO adsorption and C−C coupling while inhibiting the HER. Additionally, finite element simulation (COMSOL Multiphysics simulations) and DFT theoretical calculations provide strong evidence that introducing K+ can enhance the electric field, promoting *CO adsorption at the Cu active site, thus reducing the energy barrier of C−C coupling (Figs. 8(c) and (d)). Furthermore, the halogen modification strategy can induce cation effects, thereby promoting H2O activation. Wang et al. [115] reported a fluorine (F)-modified Cu catalyst for the CO2RR. The presence of F on the Cu surface facilitates the activation of H2O through interactions with hydrated cations, which enhances the formation of C2H4 (Fig. 8(e)). The intensity of the interaction between hydrated cations and anion species on metal surfaces is inversely correlated with n and the radius of the cation M+(H2O) n . Specifically, lower n values and smaller radii result in stronger interactions, thereby facilitating enhanced H2O activation capability [116]. Moreover, the type of anion can change the selectivity of the CO2RR. For instance, substituting Na+ with K+ markedly increased the C2H4 formation rate. Conversely, when the cation was substituted for Cs+, formic acid formation increased while C2H4 decreased [115]. 3.2 NRR/NITRR In the case of inert small molecules such as N2, cation adsorption can affect the electrochemical behavior of catalysts [13,117]. Yan et al. [102] reported that Bi catalysts combined with K+ in electrolytes synergistically promote the NRR with high activity and selectivity. Bi provides a lower free-energy change (∆G) for the pivotal potential-determining step and demonstrates superior catalytic efficacy compared to conventional transition-metal catalysts (i.e., Au). K+ regulates proton diffusion, enhancing selectivity for ammonia (NH3) and suppressing the HER (Fig. 9(a) ). A higher K+ concentration leads to increased efficiency of NH3 production (200 mmol NH3 g−1 h−1) with 66% FENH3 (Figs. 9(b) and (c)). Moreover, cations can influence the product selectivity and kinetics of the NITRR. Sánchez-Sánchez et al. [12] found that monovalent metal cations (Li+, Na+, K+, and Cs+) in electrolytes can impact the NO3 − removal rate and product (NH3) selectivity. These cations tend to form ionic pairs with the negatively charged nitrate ions (NO3 −), affecting their migration towards the negatively charged surface of the cathode [12]. They found that the cations in the electrolyte affected the product selectivity (Figs. 9(d) and (e)). The interaction between NO3 − ions and monovalent cations as ionic pairs can modify N-species coverage on the interface, thereby influencing product distribution selectivity [12]. For instance, bulky cations (such as Cs+) can decrease the N-coverage, shifting selectivity towards NH3 formation. The selectivity for NH3 increased from 15% to 39% when the electrolyte changed from LiOH to CsOH [12]. This is because Cs+ can form a strong local field at the electrode/electrolyte interface, enhancing the stabilization of intermediate species in NO3 − and NO2 − reduction processes through intensified dipole-cation interactions. 3.3 Electrocatalytic reduction of organic The cationic effect has applications in the electrocatalytic reduction of organic compounds. Recently, Zhang et al. [101] reported self-supported Pd nanotips with sulfur modifiers for the electrochemical alkyne reduction using K+ with high selectivity (96%) and FE (75%) and high conversion (>97%) (Fig. 10(a) ). The Pd nanotip structures enhance the local electric field, causing K+ to concentrate adjacent to the tips. Moreover, the mutual repulsion effect leads to a substantial decrease in the surface concentration of adsorbed OH− ions, facilitating reactive hydrogen (H*) generation, which serves as the hydrogen source for the alkyne semihydrogenation (Figs. 10(b) and (c)). In addition, our group reported a cation-adsorption strategy to enhance the catalytic activity of TiO2 for the reduction of oxalic acid [88]. Specifically, we investigated the performance of electrochemical reduction of oxalic acid (OX) in acidic electrolytes containing different metal ions (Na+, K+, Al3+, Ca2+, Mg2+, and Zn2+). The experimental results showed that better performance could be obtained in the electrolyte containing Al3+ than in the electrolytes containing other cations (such as H+, Na+, and K+) (Fig. 10(d)). A mechanistic study revealed that the presence of Al3+ in the electrolyte can promote the generation of H* and the adsorption/stabilization of OX and glyoxylic acid (GO, intermediate), thus enhancing the selectivity of glycolic acid (GA) (Figs. 10(e) and (f)) [88]. 3.4 ORR In recent years, cation effects have been used in ORR to produce hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) [53,118–120]. Pt and Pt group metal catalysts are commonly used for ORR in industrial applications, and the ORR activity is significantly affected by the nature of the cation [121,122]. Marković et al. [123,124] discovered that the interaction dynamics between hydrated alkali metal cations and adsorbed OH (OHad-M+(H2O) x ), governed by non-covalent interactions, play an important role in modulating the ORR activity on Pt (111) electrode surfaces. In particular, OHad-Li+(H2O) x exhibited the strongest interaction energy and the highest coverage of the double electric layer, resulting in fewer exposed active sites and consequently decreased ORR activity. Conversely, OHad-Cs+(H2O) x exhibited the weakest interaction energy and the highest ORR activity (Fig. 11(a) ) [123,124]. Furthermore, Bandarenka et al. [81] investigated the ORR activities of high-index Pt (221) and Pt (331) single crystals. Unlike the ORR activity order on Pt (111), the ORR activity on Pt (221) and Pt (331) surfaces followed by K+ ≫ Na+> Cs+> Rb+ ≍ Li+. This disparity is ascribed to the differences in the hydration energies and/or shell dimensions, along with the distinct influence of each alkali metal on the binding energies of the OH* species at the energetic hotspots of the Pt high-index surface. Moreover, Wang et al. [97] found that cations in acidic electrolytes (e.g., Na+) could effectively repel local protons, thereby decreasing their concentrations, inhibiting further dissociation of the generated H2O2, and preventing its conversion into H2O (Fig. 11(b)). Additionally, cation concentration can also influence ORR activity. For example, a higher concentration of cations (e.g., Na+) enhances ORR activity, which is due to the faster compensation of “activated” water molecules to the electrode surface upon their consumption in the ORR (Fig. 11(c)) [125]. Furthermore, cations can affect the activity of the oxygen reduction/evolution reaction, which in turn can impact the performance of Zn-air batteries [126–128]. Liu et al. [129] found that regulating the cations can influence the electronic properties or crystal structures of catalysts, thereby influencing their catalytic activities. The Co3+/Co2+ ratio in the MnCo2O4/NCNTs is advantageous for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and ORR, as the variable valence states of these cations provide donor-acceptor chemisorption sites that enable the reversible adsorption and desorption of oxygen. Moreover, Narayanan et al. [130] used a mixed electrolyte of KOH and LiOH to enhance the surface area and interaction between the electrode and electrolyte, thus enhancing mass and electron transfer. This enhancement leads to better conductivity and prolongs the battery life from 25 h (5 mol L‒1 LiOH) and 32 h (6 mol L‒1 KOH) to ~60 h (4 mol L‒1 KOH and 2 mol L‒1 LiOH) (Fig. 11(d)). 4 Characterization techniques Various characterization techniques are available for studying the cation effects in electrocatalytic reduction, including ex situ and in situ methods. To enhance the understanding of cation effects, we have categorized and introduced various characterization methods. Ex situ techniques such as high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), gas chromatography (GC), mass spectrometry (MS), and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) can directly reflect the influence of cationic effects on the activity of electrochemical reduction reactions. Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used to determine the concentration of cations and identify the forms of cations present on the catalyst, respectively. Electrochemical techniques such as cyclic voltammetry (CV) [110,131,132], LSV [133,134], and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) [10] have also been employed to investigate the impact of cations on the reaction. Although ex situ characterization techniques have been crucial in scientific research, they have limitations in providing real-time insights into the dynamic changes in cationic effects during reactions and their effects on the reactions. This limitation significantly constrains our understanding of cation effects. Therefore, advanced in-situ characterization techniques are urgently needed to achieve real-time analysis of complex chemical reaction mechanisms. Recently, researchers have developed a series of in-situ characterization techniques to better understand the impact of cations on electroreduction reactions. These techniques include in-situ Raman spectroscopy (SHINERS), in situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, ATR-SEIRAS, electrochemical surface X-ray diffraction (EC-SXRD), and laser-induced current transient (LICT). Li et al. [135] employed SHINERS to explore the mechanisms governing the organized assembly of interfacial water molecules and the effects of localized cationic disturbances on the molecular architecture of water interfaces. The schematic of SHINERS comprises a three-electrode system (Fig. 12(a) ). This technique (SHINERS) is ideal for probing water-rich interfaces due to the strong signal enhancement originating from the electromagnetic field at the junction between the shell-isolated nanoparticles (SHINs) and the substrate (Fig. 12(b)). Moreover, FTIR was used to understand the structure and impact of potential-dependent cation effects on catalytic activity [133,136]. ATR-SEIRAS is a powerful technique providing molecular-level insights into species at the electrochemical interface, enabling the determination of small molecule concentration (e.g., CO2) near the electrode surface. Schematic diagrams of the ATR-SEIRAS are shown in Figs. 12(c) and (d). This technique allows direct comparison of spectral feature intensities obtained with different cations [94,111]. Xu et al. [94] used this technique to monitor the concentration of interfacial dissolved CO2, showing that the concentration of dissolved CO2 decreases as the size of alkali metal cations increases at −0.8 V vs. RHE. In addition, EC-SXRD was developed to characterize the atomic structure at the electrochemical interface [137]. Yagi et al. [60] used EC-SXRD to analyze the electrochemical behavior of cations on graphene surfaces. Adsorption of K+ ions on the graphene surface (at −1.15 V vs. Ag/AgCl) caused significant changes in the crystal truncation rod (CTR) curve, which did not occur at positive potentials where K+ desorption occurs. Moreover, the LICT technique can determine the potential of maximum entropy (PEM), associated with the EDL structure and energy barriers at the interface for electrochemical reactions [138]. Fischer et al. [139] used the LICT technique to analyze the cation enhancement effect on the OER. Laser irradiation of the electrode surface during the experiment induced a temperature increase, disrupting ordered water dipoles in the EDL and causing disorder. This rapid relaxation led to sharp positive or negative current transients and changes in the PEM (Fig. 12(e)). Faster OER occurs when the PME is closer to the thermodynamic equilibrium [139]. 5 Theoretical calculation methods Researchers commonly utilize theoretical calculations to understand cation effects on reduction reactions, primarily through the use of ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations [75,97,111] and COMSOL Multiphysics simulations [101]. AIMD simulations are excellent tools for studying atomic-level interactions and cation dynamics during reduction reactions [55], providing detailed insights into the electronic structure and behavior of the system under various conditions. Li et al. [140] used AIMD to simulate the atomic structure of interfacial water on Pd/Au, revealing the positioning of the electric field between the electrolyte and metal surface. On the other hand, COMSOL Multiphysics simulations are used to model macroscopic properties and phenomena, such as the electric field distribution and ion transport, influencing overall reaction kinetics and efficiency [58]. In particular, for catalysts with tip structures, COMSOL Multiphysics simulations can assess the local electric field intensity and the enrichment capability for K+ ions [100]. By combining these two approaches, researchers can achieve a comprehensive understanding of how cations affect reduction reactions at both molecular and continuum scales. 6 Conclusion and outlook In this review, we summarize the current knowledge, including the mechanism, application, characterization techniques, and theoretical calculation analysis of cation effects. Cations in the electrolyte can (1) adsorb/stabilize reactants/intermediates, (2) tune the local electric field, (3) buffer the interfacial pH, and (4) influence HER activity. Theoretical analyses, such as COMSOL Multiphysics simulations and advanced characterization techniques, like ATR-SEIRAS, have provided powerful explanations for cation effects. These advantages have led to the development of numerous theoretical models aimed at rationalizing the role of cations in electrocatalytic processes. However, some critical issues remain to be resolved (Fig. 13 ). (1) Although researchers have proposed mechanisms for various cationic effects, revealing the specific mechanism of the interface electric field effect more accurately remains challenging due to the complexity of the reaction interface. For instance, electric field distribution and intensity are mainly determined based on DFT calculations. Therefore, conducting deeper studies on the mechanisms of the cation effects is necessary. (2) As previously reviewed, the influence of “cation effects” on the electrocatalytic reduction reaction is very complex, emphasizing the need for further studies on the interaction between electrodes and electrolytes. Moreover, current characterization of cation effects relies primarily on in-situ ATR-SEIRAS, in-situ TR-SERS, vibrational Stark spectroscopy, theoretical calculations, and simulations. However, these methods cannot fully elucidate the fundamental reasons for cation effects. Therefore, developing new characterization techniques to identify the dominant mechanisms underlying specific reaction/cation systems under operating conditions is necessary. (3) As reviewed in the “The mechanism of cation effects” section, cation effects present challenges such as catalyst instability, and salt precipitates that need to be addressed. To tackle these issues, researchers have proposed using nitrogen-containing cations (such as trimethylammonium, piperidinium, pyridinium, and imidazolium groups) as substitutes to avoid the salting-out effect caused by the aggregation of cations at high concentrations. For instance, researchers have applied crosslinked poly-(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) to cover a catalyst, which suppresses the mass transport of H+ and tunes the interfacial field strength. This strategy provides a sustainable pathway for electroreduction in acidic environments. However, it also introduces the new issue of poor catalyst stability. Consequently, future research should focus on developing innovative methods and strategies to improve catalyst stability. (4) Catalyst modification strategies for managing cation effects are relatively limited. Strategies such as the tip effect and ligand/heteroatom doping alter the interfacial electric field, local pH, and substrate adsorption capacity, thereby enhancing the activity and selectivity of the reactions. However, research on the design of catalytic strategies for specific reactions, crucial for enhancing the practical application of cation effects in catalytic processes, has not been sufficiently developed. Future studies should focus on exploring and developing advanced modification strategies (e.g., amorphous single-atom or diatomic research, van der Waals heterojunctions, microenvironment regulation, spin state regulation, and amorphous 2D layered material coupling) to enhance the cation effects in electrocatalytic reduction reactions. (5) The relationships between different catalytic systems are intertwined and complex. In terms of intermediate states and reaction pathways, various catalytic systems (light, electricity, heat, enzyme catalysis, etc.) are essentially identical. Therefore, it is necessary to understand the effects of cations on other systems. For example, in a photocatalytic reaction system, Cs+ in the electrolyte interacts with BiVO4 photoanodes to form a Cs+-doped bismuth vanadium oxide amorphous thin layer, which suppresses the continuous photocorrosion of BiVO4 and facilitates water splitting. Therefore, it is important to develop cations for other catalytic applications. (6) To date, most studies on cation effects have focused on influencing the activity and selectivity of electrocatalytic reduction reactions, with only a few studies addressing electrooxidation reactions. For instance, cation effects can be used to tune the selectivity of anodic glycerol oxidation, enriching our understanding of the microstructures at the electrode-electrolyte interface. Therefore, there is still much scope for the development and exploration of suitable electrooxidation reactions involving cationic effects. (7) Currently, the influence of cations on electrocatalytic reduction reactions occurs primarily through the enrichment of hydrated cations at the catalyst interface and the regulation of reaction activity via non-covalent interactions between the electrolyte cations and intermediates. Few studies have focused on embedding cations within the catalyst structure to synergistically enhance catalytic activity. Therefore, an in-depth exploration of the dynamic changes in the bulk structure of electrocatalysts caused by cation intercalation may provide new insights into the development of cation effects. In short, the introduction of cations into the reaction system significantly enhances the activity of the reactions and holds great benefits for the further development of electroreduction reactions. We hope that this review will provide a valuable reference and inspiration in the electrochemical field for clean energy production and green chemical synthesis. Mingfei Shao (State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology) received his Ph.D. degree from Beijing University of Chemical Technology (BUCT) in 2014, after which he joined the staff of BUCT and was promoted to professor in 2018. He was also a visiting student at the University of Oxford in 2013. His research interests mainly include electrochemical energy related chemistry, materials and engineering. He proposed the idea of the water electrolysis coupled with green electrosynthesis (e.g., hydrogen generation coupled with organic oxidation). He also proposed a new method of integrated electrode design based on layered double hydroxides, which is a platform for construct various energy materials and devices. He has been published more than 130 papers, which have been cited >13000 times (H index = 62). In addition, He has obtained and awarded from the National Natural Science Foundation of China–Outstanding Youth Foundation in 2019 and the Chinese Catalytic Rookie Award. Zhenhua Li (College of Chemistry, Beijing University of Chemical Technology), received his B.S. in 2014 and Ph.D degree in 2019 from Beijing University of Chemical Technology. In 2017, he completed a joint doctoral training program at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore; From 2019 to 2023, he served as an associate professor at Beijing University of Chemical Technology, and promoted to professor from 2024. His research interests lie in the field of water electrolysis for hydrogen production couple with organic synthesis. He has published over 70 SCI papers, with more than 5800 citations, 11 ESI highly cited papers, and an H-index of 41. In the last five years, he has led a National Key R&D Program (Hydrogen Special)-Young Scientist Project, a National Natural Science Foundation of China-Youth Program, a Beijing Natural Science Foundation-Youth Program, and participated in two National Natural Science Foundation of China Major Programs. Liang Xu received her PhD degree in Chemical Engineering and Technology from Beijing University of Chemical Technology (BUCT) (China) in 2019. She did postdoctoral research at the Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences from 2020 to 2023. Then she served as a lecturer at BUCT. Her research interests mainly focus on the electrocatalytic conversion of CO2/NOx into high value-added chemicals.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic reduction reactions, powered by clean energy sources such as solar energy and wind, offer a sustainable method for converting inexpensive feedstocks (e.g., CO2, N2/NO x , organics, and O2) into high-value-added chemicals or fuels. The design and modification of electrocatalysts have been widely implemented to improve their performance in these reactions. However, bottlenecks are encountered, making it challenging to further improve performance through catalyst development alone. Recently, cations in the electrolyte have emerged as critical factors for tuning both the activity and product selectivity of reduction reactions. This review summarizes recent advances in understanding the role of cation effects in electrocatalytic reduction reactions. First, we introduce the mechanisms underlying cation effects. We then provide a comprehensive overview of their application in electroreduction reactions. Characterization techniques and theoretical calculation methods for studying cation effects are also discussed. Finally, we address remaining challenges and future perspectives in this field. We hope that this review offers fundamental insights and design guidance for utilizing cation effects, thereby advancing their development.
